name: LEGO Watch(Model: 9002137)

reviews.review_text: Bought this for my coworker. She loved it! It wasn't as small as I thought. In comparison to to my magic bullet with it sitting down, it's still bigger than my magic bullet base.
reviews.review_header: She loved it! It wasn't as small as I thought

reviews.review_text: This product looks so good in my bedroom!!! However, I consider that the product can be improved in several details. Suggestions: 1. I think the alarm sound of the alarm clock could be changed by a selection of sounds topics (minimum 5) of the film "Star Wars". 2. The lighting time to set the alarm time and the time could be extended from 5 to 10 seconds.
reviews.review_header: This product looks so good in my bedroom

reviews.review_text: Easy to use and adorable. We got this Stormtrooper alarm clock for our seven-year-old son. It is very easy to set up, unlike many alarm clocks. It has a digital screen which is not lit up at night but it lights up easily if you push down on the Stormtrooper's helmet. When the alarm goes off it makes a beeping noise which increases in speed until it eventually turns off on its own. If you want to turn it off sooner you simply push on the helmet and it stops. I think this is a great alarm clock for kids.

It's very cool looking. I must admit that I wish the alarm was more interesting than the standard annoying buzzer. Can we get some Star Wars music? It seems made okay but I question how well it will hold up. You hit his head to snooze it (which of course makes kids just want to hit the head as this also lights up the display).
reviews.review_header: Cute for a Star Wars Fan

reviews.review_text: The clock is as described and my son loves using it. It's easy for him to operate (he's 7) but the back light/snooze function does not work very well. I don't know if it's just the one we received but you have to press the head 5-8 times to get it to work. In a way it's good because he can't snooze it and go back to sleep but he also can't check the time when he wakes up in the middle of the night. Wasn't worth returning and waiting for a new one so we are just dealing with not having those functions easy to use.

Coolest clock ever. My 3-yr-old son LOVES it! He was having a hard time getting up for preschool, so we got him this clock. The first day we put it in his room, he got up right when the alarm sounded. And he was so proud of himself knowing how to turn it off like a "big boy." It is easy to use and read. Great purchase!

Well, we have already the Darth Vader version, so going for the storm trooper was our next step. The clock is of good size and has alarm that you can snooze by pressing the head. It has a lighted display that you activates again by pressing the head. It uses batteries, you can move the arms and legs. Its a really good item for any in love with star wars

My nephew loved this and wanted to use it Christmas night in his room. I would say this is best as a fun novelty item. He is 6 and is not likely to actually use an alarm clock at his age. Seems well made and the arms and legs are movable. The screen lights up when you press down on the head. Altogether a fun item and a great introduction into using an alarm clock!

name: LEGO MINDSTORMS EV3 31313 Robot Kit with Remote Control for Kids, Educational STEM Toy for Programming and Learning How to Code (601 pieces)

reviews.review_text: We have a ton of Lego kits so we are already Lego fans in my household. After you built enough Castles, Pirate ships and Fortresses, the models either get put away or they collect dust. I bought a used Mindstorms RCX kit used, 8 or 9 years ago and it was too much of a hassle with the IR tower and a working computer with Windows XP. My older son really was not interested in it after working with the NXT at School as part of a Robotics team. He was one of the main people on the team that understood how to make it work at crunch time in the competition, but Robotics was too nerdy for him. This Christmas I picked up the EV3 for my younger son. He was on the Vex team as a 6th grade student last year. I was hoping to do more on our own since the VEX team is not together this year. As aside note, I participated as a parent in the FLL with when my older son was in middle school and we made the trip with his team to compete at LegoLand. Last year I went to a Vex Tournament and I thought FLL was better at the middle school age group. The format was better and the kids really took pride being able to compete at LegoLand. Back to now - My son quickly built a couple robots that are on shown on the box and the kit got shelved till last week; we have many competing activities so finding projects that would capture his interest was the goal. We found the Mindcub3r Rubik's Cube Solver Robot. This one project really was fun and got my son really interested in the kit again. For us, the project was a medium difficulty level build. It used only pieces from the 31313 kit. Everyone who has seen this Robot is amazed and he was asked to bring it to school. Go to home depot and buy a large parts bin organizer or maybe even the DeWalt DWST14825 here on Amazon might work. It is easier to keep all the lego parts sorted and together. Before you buy any parts bin organizer you just have to make sure there a compartment that will fit the EV3 computer. You really need to go online and look for other projects and information as what comes in the box is good, but limited. We purchased "The LEGO MINDSTORMS EV3 Discovery Book" and my son is already excited to take apart the Rubik's Cube Robot we built and start working on the workbook. Both the Rubik's Cube Bot and the projects in the workbook only need the 31313 kit. $350 might seem like a good chunk of change to put down on something like this, they resell well on eBay if it does not catch on with your kids, but I think as a parent you have to get involved too. I recommend getting the workbook with the kit. I have been looking through the woorkbook and it has some good information and good teaching moments. We are starting the workbook projects tomorrow, so I will update this review in the future.
reviews.review_header: Great Kit with Huge Learning Opportunity

reviews.review_text: I have waited for two years to write this review. There's a good reason for it. I first bought these as a Christmas gift for my son when he was nine/fourth grade. The reason was that we had sent him to a day camp for a week that same year, and this was what they were using. EDIT: I did not know at the time that there was a difference in the "retail" vs. "educational" kits, and my son was getting frustrated over some of the things that he could not get the mindstorms to do that he could do at camp. If you get/got these after a Lego robotics camp, it's important to keep that in mind. END EDIT. He was initially ecstatic about them. He and my husband built a few things, and although my son is really focused on science and math, trying to build something on his own was intimidating for him. He didn't really want to build anything unless my husband could guide him. That wasn't what we were going for - my husband is a great dad and spends a lot of time with our son, but our goal was for my son to use his imagination and start creating things himself. We installed the software on my laptop, but as I was working from home at the time, that situation led to issues with trying to get things to work. I found myself really resenting that I shelled out SO much money for toys that were just sitting there. We would find ourselves saying, "Why don't you go do something with your mindstorms?" and he'd look at us like he was being punished. Over the course of the next year, he would build a few things, but only sporadically. Fast forward to sixth grade/age 11. He's matured a bit (as much as one can expect of an 11-year-old). But I mean he's got more initiative and can create things without feeling the need to have dad with him. He does have a low-end smartphone, and we said he should get the mindstorms app so he doesn't have to rely on my laptop. He's creating all kinds of things, sending them into the living room to show us while he's in his room. I think that even for a kid who was so geared toward things like this at age nine, he needed more time to really get into these. He's never been one to just build a lego set and keep it that way; he always pulls them apart to create things on his own, and those are usually pretty cool. I guess I thought that he would have been the same way with these, but perhaps the mindstorms were a little overwhelming. I'm not really sure, but I think my tip for anyone is that if their kid doesn't fully get into these right away, give it time. My son is actually using these as part of his science fair project this year.
reviews.review_header: Might be intimidating/overwhelming for some younger kids, but mine is finally into mindstorms.

name: LEGO Ideas Exo Suit 21109

reviews.review_text: This is just so much fun on so many levels. The unique, green semi-classic space figures delightfully accent the set. They provide just enough color to breathe life into the monochrome mech, without spoiling its complex but utilitarian ruggedness. The traditional space logos and 2nd generation helmets with flip-up visors are a welcome bit of nostalgia, and in brand new vibrant green! The pictures of the Exo Suit and turtle on the box look completely light/dark gray, however some of those elements are actually silvered pieces, which enhance the metallic theme. As mentioned in several reviews here, the build is somewhat intricate, making use of mainly small parts. Often in clever and surprising ways. It was not tedious to put together, and didn't take long. But the build is different than your typical set. For example, the largest pieces in the suit are a 2x6 plate, followed by a 2x4 plate -- and only one of each! Even the ball and socket joints use only short segments, with the arms and legs built up from axles and linkages. The finished model has excellent articulation and posability. Particularly the hands and legs. Also, LEGO has consistently provided extras of the smallest, easiest to lose pieces. Which seems to be most of this set! I had around a dozen extra parts, from rounds to flats to wrenches to spikes to a spacesuit tank and visor. Even still, they have a customer service contact and a complete part listing at the end of the manual, just in case. The instruction book and short story are another nice touch, as usual in several languages. The only drawback was the insets naming some sections of the exosuit seemed to be out of order or on the wrong pages. The instructions were clear and fine, just the annotation seemed to be out of place (wrong page refs in the source file?). Very minor distraction. And in no way diminishes from the sheer awesomeness of this LEGO Ideas set. I hope to see many more of this caliber produced over the coming decades. Finally, I appreciated the sales pitch text saying the design was modular, and encouraged tuning it to your mission. This kind of thinking embodies the creative spirit of LEGO, and the sharing and tweaking and expanding the ideas of others. Thanks for making this set available at a reasonable price for the piece count. And special thanks to the designer (Peter Reid) for doing the work and getting this out there. I'll have to check out your LEGO Space book! (Though a note of caution: When I finished building the Exo Suit, Yve jumped into the cockpit to test it out. Pete grabbed the walkie talkie. He's only scowling because he's trying to sweet talk his way out of the dexterous but gentle grip of an expertly wielded Exo Suit claw... She's grinning ear to ear...) Thanks and happy building.
reviews.review_header: Fun classic but modern space set, and sweet to have it come from LEGO Ideas

reviews.review_text: I am so glad I bought this set. This model has reawakened my inner child. The build is fun & challenging. It uses more technic parts instead of traditional lego bricks so it may be harder for younger kids to build. The finished product is highly posable and fun to look at. It comes with 2 classic space mini figures and a robot turtle (also very cool). Buy it before it retires!
reviews.review_header: One of the best lego sets I ever bought.

reviews.review_text: My son asked for this set for his 10th birthday and is really, really happy with it. He is always building robotic dinosaurs and "mechs" using similar techniques, so when he saw this Exo Suit he was so excited. It took him about an hour to build, maybe less (hard to tell because he had to keep stopping for silly things like dinner, homework, and drum lessons), and he was easily able to complete it without any help. Even before he had it half built, he was going on and on about how cool it was. The finished model looks great and is easy to pose and balance standing up. It has a lot of interesting uses of different pieces in ways you might not normally build with, so it's fun that way. I can also see how using pieces in new ways can inspire kids to think creatively about their own projects. My son said he loved the way the legs of the Exo Suit were jointed "like a lizard or dinosaur," and he noticed it even looks awesome from the back. The retro look of the astronauts (and one is a girl, yay Lego!) is a nice touch and the turtle/rover is just plain cute. Of course, the beauty of Lego is that you can adjust it to do your own thing. After playing with the finished set for a while, my son said he thought the arms were a bit too long and that the claws were "too much." He then set about rebuilding them to suit his own taste, resulting in a suit with no claws, fewer fingers, and slightly shorter arms -- with a little help from Lego pieces in his own collection. I have no doubt this is a model that will be played with, displayed, and not taken apart to build something else.

I absolutely love this set! I really wish Lego would create for sets similar to this regarding exo-suits or robots. I purchased this set to create a Brickfilm using the exo-suit and a simple story line but this set has so much more to it. I've found a number of other configurations you can make with the pieces and its just so darn cool looking. I also like that you get two minifigs that are green space figures and not the generic red or blue. I can't recommend this set enough! My boys were fascinated with it and once I created a simple video using the set they were even more jazzed about it.
reviews.review_header: One of the coolest lego space sets you can buy! Hands down!

reviews.review_text: This only occupied my child for about 40 minutes. I primarily purchase Legos to alleviate the stress and responsibility of good parenting but this didn't provide nearly enough "me" time. Buy this product cuz as soon as lego stops making it then some middle aged lego nerd on amazon will charge $200 for it.
reviews.review_header: I primarily purchase Legos to alleviate the stress and responsibility of good parenting but this didn't provide nearly enough "m

reviews.review_text: This is a really incredible Lego set. It's smaller than its part count might suggest but it's shockingly poseable and looks truly impressive. Display value is through the roof. Play value is pretty high although there are some pieces that fall off pretty easily. It contains a lot of high value technic pieces that are sure to come in handy if you decide to disassemble. The green classic space minifigs are sure to hold their value. Like a lot of the new lego sets, this contains spares of a lot of the smaller pieces.
Nice challenging kit with many small parts. Construction is mostly axles and pins rather than bricks. The finished model is very posable.
reviews.review_header: Nice challenging kit with many small parts

reviews.review_text: I love this set. Once built, you can articulate all the joints and pose the suit in nearly infinite configurations. The green minifig suits are a nice color along with the old-school space logo. The build was complex enough to keep me engaged, but not so difficult that it was frustrating. P.S. - the little turtle is super cute too!

name: LEGO Classic Large Creative Brick Box 10698

reviews.review_text: Lego classics are awesome! I am somewhat partial, I loved Legos as a child and these classics remind me of my Lego buckets. I'm guessing Lego responded to public demand for something other than a kit to build a specific item. Lego in general are educational, the kits have taught my 5 and 3 year old to follow directions without having to read and the larger kits have provided us with fun family time. This collection will inspire them to use their imagination to build whatever they please in whatever color they wish. I have attached two pictures to show how the bricks are bagged and the back paper of the exact bricks you will receive. Several windows, doors, baseplates, wheels, ramps, dots, building bricks, smooth finishing pieces - see picture for exact color and number of each piece. The yellow storage brick is also nice if you do not already have a place for your Legos. I am planning on using it as decor for their Lego themed bday party. If you are looking for other Lego storage options, ikea trofast drawer system was an inexpensive way to organize by color. If you are just getting introduced to Legos, do not expect it to be full once the bags are opened and dumped. You will receive 790 pieces and this retails for $60. At the Lego rule of 10 cents per Lego, this seems to be a great deal. This box full of Legos would be hundreds of dollars. Lego has been around for generations so there isn't a question of durability or craftsmanship. If you need an activity for your children, looking to add to an existing set, giving a gift for a Lego lover this set will be a perfect choice. Anyone who gets involved with Legos knows the obsession that follows to have more bricks, so just add on! I also recommend the classic bright set, that was a great purchase to add the "girl" colors to my boys collection of stereotypical boy colors. The classic medium set was ok, but I probably wouldn't purchase that again, I would get the bright set or this large box again.

The picture is the biggest house I could build exclusively with ALL of the 4x2 bricks included in this set. As you can see, its just enough to be high enough to cover the minifigures head (not included), but there are not enough left to build a roof. Yes, you could finish the house with other pieces, but at this price, I should have enough 4x2's to build a reasonably sized house. 4x2 bricks are the workhorse of creative building with Lego, no matter how much LEGO has attempted to market smaller, more complex and specific creations as the 'new' heart of Lego, and not buildings and houses. Any child who grew up with Lego knows its *ALL* about the 4x2. This is a 790 piece set, with only *67* 4x2 bricks. On average, most colors only have FOUR 4x2 bricks - !? The 4x2 is relatively large and expensive, so Lego sells sets with really high piece count - like this one at 790 - but uses tiny pieces no one cares about to push up the piece count. In this case, only 8% of the pieces are 4x2's. ...and I love Lego's response to people's complaints about 4x2's - 'hey, come to our website and buy by the BRICK' - where 4x2 pieces are $.30/pc! I don't even think LEGO *wants* to sell these building sets anymore (this set was created 'by demand!'), because the vertical sales of endless expensive, complicated *model* sets of licensed characters (like its own, or Batman, Star Wars, etc) are much more lucrative. Most of these sets aren't even buildable by kids until they are competent readers who can follow complex instructions, and once they have built it, the bricks have little or no replayability. Build the model, you're done. Did I mention these model sets seem half the size of as the picture on the box? Some of Lego's model sets are completely phoned in as well - the original Minecraft sets, for example - uh, my kids and I have played ALOT of Minecraft - the original Minecraft sets - I don't even know what they were *supposed* to look like - they looked like a mess - and, of course, where Minecraft is a game of large 1 meter square blocks, the LEGO version was comprised of tons of the tiniest pieces I have ever seen. Once we opened the box, we didn't even bother building our Minecraft set, it was so disappointing. Having bought only one other model sets other than the Minecraft one, I don't even like my kids to see the model sets in the store - because yes, the cover art is exciting and cool, but I know that the out-of-the-box experience is not. Dad will wind up building the entire thing, my daughter will play with it for 5 minutes, start taking some pieces apart, and it will be nothing more than a mess of tiny toy pieces no one plays with for the rest of its lifespan. I have talked to other parents, and Lego's strategy is a universal disappointment. Lego, the 'CLASSIC' Lego experience is having a child open their first set of legos, which is mostly 4x2, so they can build big, beautiful buildings of their own imagination. You can sell your one-off model kits, but let's see you sell at least ONE set which is mostly 4x2, and bring that core experience of replayability back to kids of this generation. I chose this set because it does contain some parts I think are important for a core set - like windows, doors, and wheels - but when I see the vast number of tiny useless filler this set has, it just makes me upset about what kid's experience is with modern Lego marketing.

++ Observations: * The box isn't good as Lego storage -- a few pieces are small enough to fall through the hole on the bottom. I do advise buying a separate Lego organization solution. * The diversity of pieces is a little thoughtless, and there aren't enough basic pieces of any one color. I purchased an extra "Lego Creative Supplement" package, and still had trouble getting enough pieces for the wall and roof of the home. The kinds of pieces available to any color is also a little capricious. I wish they removed some of the colors and just gave more basic pieces. * The sole green base plate it comes with is small, and I'm surprised there isn't at least one more base plate. ++ Verdict: I wanted to take out my wallet and convert money into an ideal classic Lego introductory experience, but alas, this large classic box, even with a creative supplement, lacked the right quantity of basic pieces. I ended up going to the Lego website to buy large bundles of basic pieces in just a few basic colors, and the price was surprisingly reasonable.
reviews.review_header: Thoughtless diversity of pieces -- hard to build a home.

reviews.review_text: I love legos. Now that my 8 year old is getting into them I thought this would make great bonding time, and it does.We have bonded in our frustration with what $55 dollars gets you. NOT MUCH! Sure there is almost 800 pieces but 70% are small insignificant pieces. The bucket size is very deceiving. It is about a quarter full. There aren't enough pieces to get super creative, let alone build a house. These are fun but IMHO Lego is getting too big for their britches. Not a great value.

Box was very sturdy and all Legos were separated into bags by color. Easy to open plastic packaging and easy to see what parts each had inside. We got this for our son to add more blocks to his collection and it served the purpose it was intended for.

name: LEGO Classic Medium Creative Brick Box 10696

reviews.review_text: This set comes with a variety of 484 Legos. They are separated into bags and placed into this yellow plastic bin. Once you open the bags, it would probably take up one fifth of the bin. Do not think this bin is coming filled to the top, that would be hundreds of dollars. The bin itself would be great for storage if you needed. I am planning on saving it for their Lego themed birthday party to set up paper plates or silverware in. This is a classic set nostalgic to the bins I had as a child. I am a fan of Lego in general, I like their kits because they allow my 5 and 3 year old to create trains, cars, etc that look cool and are fun to play with. These classic kits allow for their Imaginationon to run wild as they dig in. This set came with 35 colors. I was happy with the assortment of pieces, some of the smooth finishing pieces, ramps, dot pieces, grated pieces. It had a selection of wheels and hubs, tiny size and medium. Without the tires you can create train wheels. There were several small black windows, without shutters or panes. And one tiny arch window that is pictured on the front. There's also the smooth dot eyeballs. This kit contained a few base plates, the largest was 8x16. Also a brick separator, which is really cool device so you don't have to use your teeth. Right now we are getting these classics sets to bulk up my kids collection for free building. I do like this medium set for the variety it contains. I have read that you shouldn't pay more than ten cents per Lego (accounting for differences in variety of sizes). This kit retails for $30, so with that little thought in mind it is a great price and variety. I also recommend the the $20 Lego classic bright box. It contained great colors, and didn't have wheels or windows- mostly building bricks. if you are just getting started with Legos- buy it. If you need a gift for a Lego lover- buy it. If you want to add on to your/your child's collection- buy it. Getting more Legos can never be wrong, especially when they build your child's imagination and keep them busy for hours!
reviews.review_header: great for a supplement or a starter set

reviews.review_text: The Lego Creative (Medium) Creative set comes to in a nice plastic storage box. I knew what was included, so I cannot blame Lego. There are simply not enough basic bricks to build with. I have uploaded several pictures for your review. When all is said and done, you are left with a lot of extra room in your storage box. For us, this was okay, but if your little builder wants to build a house, you may want to check out the Lego Education Basic Brick Set. That set has a lot of building bricks. This set has more specialty pieces, such as wheels. Overall, a great quality product. Lego never disappoints in that regard. This set may disappoint you IF you don't realize exactly what you are getting. I think my pictures will help you there! As you can see, there aren't many basic bricks.
reviews.review_header: See Pictures! NOT Enough Classic Bricks...

reviews.review_text: I got this box of legos for my students to use during indoor recess. The container is sturdy which is great for how many students will be handling it. The lid attached sturdily. My only complaint is that the size of the box is very misleading. If you look at the photo I attached, the pieces it comes with barely even fills the container halfway. I still think it's a pretty good deal for the container plus the pieces. I guess it leaves room for me to fill with more lego pieces as I buy more.

So in trying to give a "chest full O' legos" as a gift to a niece I discovered what I was aiming for would cost thousands of dollars if I bought it from lego. After scouring the internet for a weekend I settled on buying a ton of usa made, but CHEAP, not lego "legos" that were sold here on amazon and fit just fine with actual legos. I wound up finding 1000 mixed size building blocks for around 20 bucks. Through lego anything even close cost around or over 100 dollars and wouldn't have contained many actual building blocks. Finding anything sold by lego that had a good mix of building blocks and "flavor" or "special" connecting blocks, like axles and windows/doors, was impossible. It was mostly the special or flavor pieces and only ever a handful of proper building blocks. The only set that contained a majority of building blocks had somewhere around 1500 pieces but it cost over 150 bucks! In the end I bought this set solely as a "special" and "flavor" lego set. It gives you some axles, a door, and enough oddball and unique pieces that you can actually turn some building blocks into something other than just a tower. You can build a handful of things listed in a pamphlet that comes with it but after that the options are pretty limited without some real building blocks to throw into the mix. To sum up this is a great addition to a collection solely because there are not many other options out there that don't cost an arm and a leg and which also have as many unique pieces. Buy this and a couple of bags of cheap off brands and you've got a good start on a collection. Oh, and don't forget the extra large base boards!
reviews.review_header: not lego "legos" that were sold here on amazon and fit just fine with actual legos

reviews.review_text: I have objected to so many Lego kits because they are so specific. I miss the standard Lego bricks--the twos, fours, and eights of my childhood with a few windows and wheels--that didn't need instructions to make fun stuff: from the name of this, I thought that was what this one was however, this comes with lots of instructions. Sure, you can make cool stuff, but it still ties you to the plans rather than liberates you into the possibilities of undesigned construction. I would love to find a big box of basic lego bricks so I can make what I want, rather than what Lego wants me to make.
reviews.review_header: Not what I thought I was getting

reviews.review_text: Significantly overpriced for what was in it. Not an assortment of LEGOs as the name "Creative Brick Box" would lead you to believe. It is actually just several small LEGO model projects, with specific pieces meant for that specific model and not the general 1x1, 1x2, 2x2, 2x4, and 2x8 pieces like I expected. Other than being overpriced for what you're getting, there is nothing inherently wrong with the product, just not what was expected from a box boasting the number of pieces and the creativity of it.

name: LEGO Creator Expert Volkswagen T1 Camper Van 10220 Construction Set

reviews.review_text: I continue to be amazed by the amazing engineering that goes into turning small little brics into a 4 pound object de art. Incredibly detailed, fun, amazingly designed, super fun and funky. Did have one missing piece - a black 1 x 2 that goes on the front passenger door - but I scarfed one from my Millennium Falcon (next build) and just received replacements (free and quickly) from LEGO who are great about this stuff. Built over four sessions (give or take)...maybe 16 hours? Detailed engine. Folding table and bench seats. Kitchen/sink. Closet with mirror. Hippie art. Therapy in a box. Makes the cares of the world go away and finishing it...there's still something amazing about finishing your LEGO. Millennium Falcon is next...followed by the dreaded Tower Bridge and Sydney Opera House. I've pretty much got my next year plotted out. Thank you LEGO. Miracle in a box...and cheaper than going to the shrink.
reviews.review_header: Cool and Groovy Therapy In A Box.

reviews.review_text: It was fun and I'm 11, it wasn't to hard, it was detailed and the directions were clear.

I purchased the retro VW camper van for my eleven year old grandson who loves all things camping vehicles as well as Legos. There are over 1300 pieces and the age range states 16+ but as he is meticulous at following the directions I thought he could handle it. He said it was "by far the hardest one yet," however he completed it in a few days with marvelous results. And, unlike many of the small sets, the camper van is very large with intricate detailing. I have attached a photo of the result.

So much fun! I'm an adult LEGO collector and this is one of the most enjoyable sets I've experienced (second only to the original Arkham Asylum). So much detail and such intricate components to recreate a truly iconic vehicle of the era. The engine is just amazing. The roof vent with a fabric curtain, the closet with a reflecting mirror, the tiny shelves on the door, the lava lamp, and (my favorite part) the seat that collapses into a bed. The only downside is the fragility of the roof structure. If you're showing off your new structure to your friends, the roof could start shedding parts when you try to take it off, much to your chagrin. *ack* Also, as an aside, Hippie Lego minifigure pairs perfectly with this set. :)

My 9-yr old has just finished building this. It's Expert-level, so it required quite a bit of time and patience to get it done, including a complete re-sort of all the pieces by color. But the finished van looks great, and she is very proud of her achievement.

Really a cool set! This is the my favorite Lego set until now. I have several other Star Wars sets, but I have to say they are not as good as this one, since this is a running car :). Maybe I will try some train sets in the future, if they are not very expensive... I will suggest buying this set from Lego official online store if you are not in a hurry. The price is similar (pre-tax), and you can earn VIP rewards, and get some free items there. Hope everyone enjoy it!

The build was not as intuitive as a many other builds (this might be a positive or negative depending on your perspective). The reduced stars are for missing pieces and a very fragile final build. The moving parts are very clever but also quite tenuously attached. Normally I build the sets and my daughter plays with them for quite a while before I have to rebuild anything. This started falling apart before I was even done.

My very first Lego build on my own! I had so much fun putting this kit together! It took me about 5 days total and, while my fingertips were pretty sore after all those tiny pieces, I had a blast with it! There is a "loose" organization to the pieces so even though the bags aren't numbered I kept each bag separate. It made finding pieces much easier.

name: Brickyard Building Blocks Building Bricks - 1,100 Pieces Compatible Toys Bulk Block Set with 154 Roof Pieces, 2 Free Brick Separators, and Reusable Storage Box with Handle (1,100 pcs)

reviews.review_text: I have bought hundreds of LEGO sets and have QA experience at a plastics plant, so I was very picky when I tested this product. I will buy more of this set for sure. I built identical buildings with lots of brick brands and this did better than LEGO! It was the only set I tested that came with a guarantee which was impressive as well. The sizes and shapes of bricks reflect wonderfully what kids actually NEED in order to build what they most often build. (LEGO was always very skewed toward small pieces with only 1 or 2 token large bricks per set.) By my calculation, this set had 29% more of the larger pieces than the equivalent LEGO set (discontinued) as well as plenty of the most valuable 2x2 and 2x4 pieces because most projects use this size of brick. This company is the only brand I tested that has a 2x2 plate piece which is something kids have asked me for year after year and LEGO never offered in their basic set. There are lots of large plates which are invaluable for cars, planes, and animals which are the first things most kids try to build. (I really wish there were enough wheels to make 2 or 3 cars because I always have to buy those separately and the color brown for things like trees, hair, and skin, but most beginning builders don't focus on color much so that is a minor detail.) The packaging was nice, with a parts list on the side which I love.
reviews.review_header: This set actually made more stable buildings than LEGO!

reviews.review_text: Let me start off by saying that nobody is paying me for this review nor did I get a discount on the product. I love these blocks. I bought my 4 yr old son legos for Christmas. The box only came with 484 legos and was $45. That's not many. He needed more but I couldn't afford lego brand. When I came across these for a fraction of the price I was skeptical, but after reading the positive reviews I gave it a go. I'm not disappointed, neither is he. They fit with the lego brand perfectly, they are great quality aND I will definitely buy more later as needed. Also this is the ONLY company that has ever emailed me just to be sure I'm satisfied. I am beyond satisfied. You will be too

We LOVE these blocks! Total match to all 'other' building blocks, perfect fit. (See photos below.) We have a very happy four year old here creating to his heart content! Great colors, great variety, really great deal for the money. ( Worked out to be cheaper than per pound used ones on EBay.) Also: love the fact the box is totally full, not wastefully bigger than needed. (Though they could skip some of the extra little bags inside, though) And: seems to be a great company. They wrote to make sure all was good and as ordered. We liked that! We highly recommend these blocks and we will be buying more when we need more. Enjoy and happy building! See photos: what's in the box, stuff that was built, how perfectly they fit with Legos.

We like the Lego brand, but sometimes we need a lot of bricks without paying an exorbitant amount of money. The 1,100 piece kit from Building Bricks was exactly what we were looking for. The Big Questions: 1. Do they really work well with Lego Brand Legos? Yes - they work very well. It's difficult to tell the difference if you're not really trying hard. 2. How much cheaper are they? Is it really worth it? It's hard to compare exact pricing here because this set does not include wheels, doors or special pieces. If I had to choose a product to compare it to, I'd probably compare it with Lego's XXL Classic Box (https://www.amazon.com/10697-Building-Large-Creator-Pieces/dp/B00XJ5C4FW). When pricing per piece, the Lego box is about 5¢ per piece. And yes, you read that right. You're dolling out a nickel for every piece of plastic with Lego's brand stamped on it. :) Building Bricks runs about 3¢ per piece. So the answer is: It's almost half the price - very worth it if you're just needing a lot of standard pieces. As a side note: We really liked the color choices Building Bricks made. They're perfect for expanding your Lego creation palette.
reviews.review_header: We like the Lego brand, but this is what we needed...

reviews.review_text: my grandson is obsessed with Lego building. I found these and it said they were compatible with legos, I was a bit skeptical but the price was so much better than a comparable size set of brand name blocks I decided it was worth a try. They are perfect. I will probably get more for him.

As a lifelong Lego fan with a 5 year old daughter who is now getting into building bricks, my biggest complaint with Lego is the price. They are fantastic, but the 1000 piece Educational set runs upward of $60, and the 800+ piece Classic set about $50. I've looked at bulk blocks but consistently found lackluster reviews normally stating "Doesn't fit with Lego as advertised" or "pieces seem of lesser quality". I stumbled upon Brickyard bricks and saw the tons of high reviews and also the great pricing. 1100 pieces for $30 is a STEAL. They arrived and the pieces are almost indistinguishable from Lego brand bricks. They fit with Lego bricks tight and seem of the same quality of material. The only discernable difference is the Brickyard bricks don't have the Lego name on the top studs of the bricks. Paired with the 10x10 inch baseplates (also very amazing products, even better than Lego brand ones), they are a great deal. Lots of bank for the buck! Highly recommend these sets for anyone looking to expand their building brick collections!
reviews.review_header: An absolute STEAL of a product!

name: LEGO Architecture 21030 United States Capitol Building Kit (1032 Piece)

reviews.review_text: Very pleased with this kit. I received it as a (42nd) birthday present and built it over the course of three evenings. It took about four hours total, although I probably could have cut that time in half if my kids weren't "helping" so much. I feel the Lego Architecture series has been hit and miss but this set and the White House are both top notch examples. The overall model looks great. I just have so much respect for the designers. The rotunda all by itself is mind-boggling and I love they way the handled the rows of pillars across the entry ways. Most of the exterior walls are built of 1x1 angular bricks, some facing inward to create rows of square windows, others facing outward to suggest arches & round windows. There is an interior space detailing the floor under the rotunda, including a circle of statues, that can be viewed by lifting the rotunda off; a nice little touch. The finished model is very impressive on display, 18" wide and about 8" high. One gripe & one suggestion. First my only complaint, the back side of the model does not have nearly the level of detail as the front and sides. This is a real pity because the actual Capital Building has some unique features on the front & rear faces, and I would like to see the designer tackle both. I'm sure this was a cost saving decision made to keep the price & piece-count down, but it's a shame that the model isn't equally detailed from all sides. And a suggestion: Unlike some large Lego projects, the bags in this kit are not numbered. This is a shame, as it's really nice to open one bag at a time and only deal with the pieces needed in the next few steps. So, before starting, get yourself several bowls and a baking tray, open all the bags and sort non-white pieces by color, sort the ocean of blue pieces by size and type. This will definitely pay off in reduced frustration as you work.
reviews.review_header: Fun build utilizing some very innovative techniques

reviews.review_text: this isn't just a gift for younger people. I'm a woman in my 60's and try to stay active. If you like puzzles or need to challenge your mind and work on hand dexterity at the same time this is a great product. This product proved to be just the perfect thing for me. You have to pay attention to detail, hand and finger dexterity is a must, your mind stays active and you can see the building transform before your eyes. It's excellent for anyone who's getting older and wanting something challenging to work on that doesn't require all sorts of other tools or accessories. And the best part is you can take it apart and re-build it another day or use the parts to try and build your own unique design.
reviews.review_header: If you like puzzles or need to challenge your mind and work ...

reviews.review_text: I bought this gift for my boyfriend for Christmas and he loved it. He's a former US Marine and now a police officer so American Pride runs deep in his heart. This lego now sits under a massive star spangled banner that once flew over the US Capitol
reviews.review_header: Great Gift for An American Patriot

reviews.review_text: I ordered this when it became available from Amazon directly. As a fan of Lego Architecture, and only missing two of their sets from that line, I was very pleased with this build. This set has a larger base than the Imperial Hotel albeit not as intricate. The Capitol is definitely a must have for Lego Architecture enthusiasts and looks amazing.
reviews.review_header: I was very pleased with this build

reviews.review_text: The Lego Architecture - United States Capitol Building (Lego model # 21030) is an excellent Lego rendition of this iconic architecture. It is one of my favorites and I am proud to own it. It takes some extra patience when building because many of the smaller Lego elements must be stacked & mounted as straight as possible to make it look its best. So I would say that even though it is a fairly easy build, it is also challenging.
reviews.review_header: Lego Architecture - United States Capitol Building (Lego model # 21030)

reviews.review_text: This is a major achievement in Lego models. Certainly the biggest Architecture set yet, this is a massive, beautiful model with tons of detail. It took me a few hours to plan out and assemble (the bags are not numbered, so have fun sorting through 1000+ pieces first) and the experience was hugely therapeutic, enjoyable and mentally stimulating. (My thumbs were a bit raw after, though!) I bought this for $92 and a week later it was on sale for $60 something. It's a steal if you see it on sale, but even at MSRP I think it's a good buy. Lego is an expensive hobby to begin with, and Architecture aims for a more adult price point, and this is the best set in that line. It's a fair price, and comes in just under the 10 cents per piece mark. A word of caution - because almost all the pieces are white, do take care of where you place this model and try to keep it clean. White legos have a tendency to become discolored over time.

My 7 yr old grandson was THRILLED with this! He actually picked out the Architectural Series because he 'likes a challenge'. Kept him entertained for 3 days straight and he was so proud that building it required using 1,000 pieces.

Excellent! LEGO does a superior job with their instruction manual, especially with this 1032 piece set. The finished model is a great display scale. It's a good challenge and one I hated to finish......, time to rip it part and rebuild. A few hours a day to prolong the fun and completed in 4 days. All parts were accounted for and there were even a few smaller pieces left over. The overall representation is very good. I'm hoping Lego will develop some classic baseball stadiums, Wrigley Field, Fenway Park, Camden Yard and the original Tiger Stadium in the smaller scale "mini" bricks like the skyline series. smaller scale similar to the skyline series. this one is a must have for your collection. similar scale of the skyline series. I like the "mini" brick scale the best.

name: LEGO Friends Heartlake Summer Pool 41313

reviews.review_text: Listening (pre-purchase) to my almost 9 year old granddaughter explain all the features this set would have, it seemed to have included more than other much higher priced sets had. Then, when my granddaughter showed me the set after she built it, she had discovered even more that it had that she hadn't noticed online. We were choosing between this & a much more expensive set that wouldn't have produced the excited phrase I got to hear many times: "And it has ____! And it has _____!" In the blanks were items like "another slide here! and a shower, and a hot tub, and it even has..!" I don't remember the feature that was a surprise to her. I like all Lego sets, but this one was better designed, cramming in more features than expected.

My 8 and 10 year old girls love LEGOs. For her most recent birthday, my daughter searched through dozens of different LEGO sets before finally deciding that the Summer Pool was the best one to add to her collection. The girls were so excited to immediately put it together when it arrived. The instructions are simple but the attention to every little detail is what I especially adore about these sets. They're just so fun. The girls can spend hours playing with them. I hope they never outgrow their love for them.
My 8 year old loves this pool set more than the last lego friends pool from a few years ago. The cabana, heart spa and swim up juice bar are her favorite parts. Lego friends delivers as usual
reviews.review_header: heart spa and swim up juice bar are her favorite parts. Lego friends delivers as usual

reviews.review_text: I purchased this for my 6 year old niece, who had a few of the smaller Heartlake sets. She immediately sat down and put it all together with very little guidance from adults and loves it. The directions were very clear and easy to follow, and the set had a lot more to it than I expected, including pool, showers, slide, a bathroom, a snack cabana, a lifeguard stand, and a hot tub next to a seating area - and of course, two girl figures with pool toys. There are LOTS of tiny pieces, so beware and be ready to search for them. Small children may need help with application of stickers as well. Very happy with this purchase!

My grand kids love them. They are Lego nuts. The extra pieces are what I like best because they seem to misplace the smaller pieces even though they have a special drawer for each type of block. When Lego first came out years ago they weren't very creative so I only bought a couple of sets for my children, but now that my grandkids are getting them they are fantastic!!! My granddaughter loves the fact that you have Legos for girls, her friends collection is growing with every house and she can put together the older kids legos just fine
